pros: My coworkers were great and very supportive despite everything our managers put us through. Unfortunately, their successes and talents were rarely recognized by management. The biggest pro was Drexel's benefits and tuition remission opportunity.
cons: I do not recommend working for Eat Right Philly at Drexel. The environment was very toxic and negative. There is high turnover and staff usually leave unhappy. Staff were not respected. Everyone was micromanaged. Inappropriate and unprofessional comments and conversations were common. Taking breaks was not encouraged and work-life balance was not respected. Management always expected the worst from staff and would accuse individuals of lying, stealing, or sneaking around when that was not the case. Racism, homophobia and transphobia were not uncommon. No support from Drexel with handling this situation.

pros: Leadership is tackling the Enrollment Cliff head on. Growth strategies and implementation of RCM places the ownership of each colleges revenue performance squarely on its Dean. Good people and culture.

Between a shrinking pool of high school graduates and disruptors to traditional delivery of higher education, this sector is no different than the for-profit sector: layoffs, reorganizations, restructures. Retention issues have plagued this University since the pandemic, plus there's the issue of safety/crime in an urban campus.

pros: Tuition remission is great. Benefits are good. Within my small department, boss is very supportive. Students are generally positive.
cons: I've seen people who were truly passionate about their work become jaded and burned out due to the lack of fair compensation and support. We are regularly reminded that Drexel's financial situation is dire, and are asked to make sacrifices and concessions. Being told to accept larger class sizes while losing staff/faculty, thus making work loads significantly larger and more difficult, is really upsetting. The university focuses on bring in more students and keeping them here, and it's not because their education is valued--it's because they bring in money. In meetings, increasing student rates is prioritized above all else. It's like higher admin and leaders see dollar signs with incoming students. Fine, bring in more students, but doing so without supporting burned out faculty who are already over-exerting themselves--giving them pitiful "raises", giving them no budget for materials, taking their classroom spaces--pathetic. I've seen many people bending over backwards to give their students a good, ethical education, on small salaries. I used to love coming to work, but sadly I count myself among the jaded people who have seen the way this corporate business treats its faculty and staff.

review_title: Great benefits, not so great administration.
pros: Drexel offers great benefits packages, amenities, and professional development for its employees. The culture at the university promotes collaboration across departments, which makes it easy to reach out to people and ask for help or work on projects together.
cons: The HR department isn't made aware of department issues unless they're reported. This is fine if people feel comfortable reporting issues, but it means that management in departments and schools can get away with shoddy work or questionable management tactics. In my department, I felt that administration wasn't communicative or made decisions without consulting people within the department. If HR were more directly embedded within the institution and not on an island, I think better quality work would get done. Also, I completed an advanced degree that directly related to my job while I worked at Drexel. I received no compensation for my new skills, no bump in responsibilities, or no opportunities to use my new skills.

pros: University environment is fun - lots of events and opportunities.  At least when I was there, the college I worked in was in a good financial position, my job felt secure, and my needs were met in terms requests for technology and professional development.  Lots of amazing co-workers, decent benefits, and the tuition remission made it hard to want to leave, despite the cons.
cons: Management within my college was somewhat of a mess.  There was not mutual respect between administration and other staff members.  Definitely not an "open door policy" in regard to meeting with the dean.  Opportunities for professional advancement were somewhat non-existent, and hiring from outside, rather than promoting from within, seemed to be the preference.

review_title: Challenging, but rewarding Ph.D. program with many opportunities for advancement
pros: There is an emphasis on collaboration and networking at Drexel - students are encouraged to spearhead collaborative projects between faculty within the school and even outside the school. I also feel that the health insurance is excellent, and offers great supplemental dental and vision insurance. Faculty are productive and active; even long-established faculty are frequently publishing in high-impact journals. There is also an abundance of young, well-funded enthusiastic faculty for students to work with.
cons: For students looking to stay in the academic world, there are not many, if any, opportunities to gain teaching experience, and these opportunities have declined over the course of my stay here. Drexel also requires a rigorous series of exams to gain full candidacy- a comprehensive preliminary exam, a mock-grant qualifying exam, and a thesis proposal written in the form of a grant. This stringent process is more demanding than at many schools, but it does ensure that those who pass through the program are capable and qualified.

pros: If you want freedom to explore your skills, learn and try out ideas, develop your leadership style, and test out different professional approaches, this is the place for you.
cons:
Low salary; merit is inflation rate (meaning no merit)

Poor communication from leadership on direction; employees are finding out internal business news through third party sources like newspapers. 
Disagreement and conflicting messages among leadership. 
Insufficient investment on internal human resource assets.
No opportunity to establish work-life balance. Or even to take lunch.

review_title: I worked part-time as a "Student Assistant" on software projects funded by the NSF.
pros: This position provided me great industry experience that helped me get future internships and jobs. The hours were flexible and most of the work was done from home (or wherever I could take my laptop). I had input on what I got to work on and freedom to make large decisions for the project.
cons: Relative to the industry, the pay is not very high but is much higher than most jobs students work (e.g. retail, food, etc.). The program is also a bit too unorganized. There were times where it felt like I had little direction or feedback due to my supervisor's other responsibilities.

pros: Drexel employs, for the most part, student-centric and talented people. It's great having an outward facing role where you work with prospective students. The benefits are great, very generous time off, and fantastic work-life balance.
cons: Very limited room for growth. The culture is very dysfunctional and communication across teams/functional areas is poor. Classic case of the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. Information sharing is limited making it challenging to do your job. Political issues are frequent, and the University is on a trend of hiring FAR too many administrators.

review_title: This was a nice administrative job.
pros: University environments are the best places to work and there is a lot of job security. Positive atmosphere with a lot of bright people and much potential for advancement. Very flexible scheduling. Most employees in every department seem to generally enjoy working there from what I've heard (as opposed to working other places at least), including facilities management and grad students, and are all very motivated, professional, and nice people.
cons: I cannot think of downsides at the moment. I think colleges everywhere should try to cut down on administrative positions to lower the costs of tuition, which is a good thing.

review_title: Drexel is both a great place to work and a frustrating place to work.
pros: Great new university President, John Fry.  Excellent tuition reimbursement program for employees and their dependents.  Many employees are truly outstanding members of the Drexel team and really do a great job for students and co-workers (some are not).  Great location for those riding public transportation.  Excellent benefits package, especially the 403b retirement program.  New President decided to close the university between Christmas and New Years day, this was a good idea and makes complete sense.  Several new buildings have been completed and more are on the way.  The campus is generally looking better everyday.  New President is making a real effort to ask for direct input and advice from students, faculty, and staff, no one can say, "They never asked me."  Excellent technology support and infrastructure. Shipping and Receiving staff do a great job delivering mail and packages.
cons:
There is no investment in employee training or advancement (except tuition assistance which is great).  My department has zero budget for anything except what goes in the classroom.

There is no incentive to work harder or better, see below. 

Raises have no connection to job performance what so ever.  As mentioned in other reviews the University chooses a percentage (i.e. 2%, 2.5%, 1.5%) and that's pretty much what you get, give or take 1/2 % point. What this amounts to is a cost of living raise.  The problem is the people making the most, over 100K per year, get double the cost of living raise than those making 50K per year.  However, the cost of living increased EQUALLY for both parties.  This unfair distribution of cola raises increases exponentially each year.  Because raises have no connection to merit (Drexel calls them "merit increases") or actual job performance, this cost of living increase should be divided equally among employees (i.e. everyone gets a $2000 raise).  Some would argue that persons holding advanced degrees and higher positions deserve to make more money, and I would agree, because they already do!  Persons holding advanced degrees and higher positions are paid at least double or triple the annual salary of persons with 4 year college degrees.  That is the reward for the higher degree or position, double or triple annual pay.  The cost of gas, electric, food, rent, taxes, insurance, and medical care, did not increase more for people with higher degrees or positions.  When bills are due they don't ask, "Do you have a Ph.D.? Yes? Okay, that will be 20 % extra then."

Bureaucracy, there is a lot of it.  Drexel has a chronic, "It's not my job" syndrome.  Many employees do not help students or other employees to the degree which they are fully capable. Some employees choose first and foremost to pass the buck and not take personal responsibility for a task or problem.  Issues that could be solved with a few minutes work, a couple of phone calls or emails, end up taking days or weeks to resolve due to, "It's not my job" syndrome and "forwarding" the problem to someone else.

Below average and truly bad employees are able to keep their jobs and will get the same percentage raise as the best employee at the University.

review_title: Great experience learned a lot from all of the positions I held here throughout my graduate work.

cons: Drexel has a terrible unwritten rule for internal promotions which caps the amount an internal applicant can receive in pay at 10% even if the 10% is well below the minimum posted salary for the job.  This is propagated from the top down.  You're better off quitting and reapplying for a new position to get a better salary than trying to get an internal promotion.

review_title: Great place to work as a developing researcher
pros: I worked at EGS with 3 different titles over the course of 4 years. My supervisors and colleagues were interesting, intelligent, and pushed me to ask unique questions and pursue curiosity. Also pay is great for well-qualified students.
cons: Maybe less of a con and more a thing to be aware of, but because EGS is so small, everyone wears lots of hats. This can be difficult, and academic work isn't always the most exciting - expect to deal with everything from making sure fidget spinners get ordered to working on million-dollar grant applications.

pros:
Drexel has a very nice gym. It is best in Philadelphia.

The department of chemical engineering is also a nice place to study
cons: It is quarter-based university. Thus, there is a huge pressure to quickly wrap up a course just in 2.5 months.

review_title: Drexel a great place for change!
pros:
The commute by train is fabulous. The benefits are great and the working hours are flexible.  The University is situated in "University City" sharing many of the same streets witht the University of Pennssylvania.  Needless to say the total student population is around 50,000 during the academic year!  

Drexel is Philadelphia’s technological leader in health sciences education.  Founded in 1891 by financier Anthony J. Drexel, the University is nationally recognized for its excellence in co-operative education and research.  The co-op program is among the nation’s oldest, largest and most successful, comprising 1,500 employers in 39 states and 12 countries.    

A leader in curricular and technological innovation, in 1983 Drexel became the first university to require all students to have microcomputers.  In 2000, Drexel became the first major university to operate a fully wireless campus.  In 2002, the University launched DrexelOne Mobile, the first wireless Web portal service for students.  Drexel is ranked sixth nationally in the 2001 Yahoo! Internet Life poll of America’s top 100 “Most Wired Universities,” and #1 for wireless access.  The library and information science program is ranked by U.S. News & World Report among the nation’s top 10 and #1 for specialized programs in information systems. A leader in athletics, Drexel is ranked #1 in the nation in athletic gender equity by U.S. News & World Report.   

The University is organized into eight colleges and three schools.  The colleges are: Arts and Sciences; LeBow College of Business; Drexel University College of Medicine; Engineering; Information Science and Technology; Media Arts & Design; Nursing and Health Professions; and Goodwin College of Evening and Professional Studies.  The schools are: Biomedical Engineering, Science and Health Systems; Education; and Public Health.

Drexel offers 62 bachelor’s programs, 63 master’s programs, 35 doctoral programs and a doctor of medicine program, and enrolls more than 16,000 students from 100 nations.  The University has more than 90,000 alumni worldwide.
cons: Parking is terrible and center city traffic is worse.  The communication between offices/departments/students and parents is abysmal.  The rule of three does not apply at Drexel - meaning transferring a call stops by the third person - the buck stops here just does not apply.  Students and parents are transferrred and transferred and transferred.  The problem is never fixed at the source and thus the problem continues.  Many letters and emails go out under the name of one office - which is not the office that handles the information but someone somewhere ultimately reports to that office and therefore the telephone number of the "top dog" is on the letterhead. Not the telephone number of department of office that is sending the letter.  Telephone calls go to the top dog and are transferred haphazardly down the line until the right office is reached.  Sometimes never.

pros: Work life balance. time off. good benefits. nice campus. easy commute. friendly people.

review_title: Drexel budget shortfalls solved by doubling student body and laying off staff.
